transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Hi, is this Zhi? Hi, this is Arjun calling from MongoDB. Do you have a minute to chat?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, this is Zhi. Uh, I have a few minutes. What’s this about?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Awesome, thanks. I noticed Acme Corp. has been running MongoDB on-prem, and I actually came across a post about some recent scaling challenges your team faced with your gaming backend. Does that sound familiar?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Um, yeah, our player numbers spiked and, honestly, it’s been rough keeping up. Our clusters get overloaded during events.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: I totally get that. That’s actually really common with fast-growing titles. I wanted to see if you’ve had a chance to look into MongoDB Atlas—our fully managed cloud platform. It’s designed to handle those spikes seamlessly.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: We've looked briefly, but honestly, we’re worried about cloud costs. Our CFO is already on me about infrastructure spend.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: That makes sense, and pricing is definitely top of mind for a lot of folks I talk to. The nice thing with Atlas is you only pay for the resources you use, and there’s no more overprovisioning. Plus, we’ve seen teams actually cut total cost of ownership by automating backups, scaling, and maintenance.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: I mean, sure, but aren’t there migration headaches? Moving production data for a live game feels risky.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: You're right, migration is a big concern. We actually have a dedicated migration team, and most gaming clients—especially those with live player data—end up using our live migration service that syncs data in real time, so there’s zero downtime.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Hmm, okay. But my team is also skeptical about vendor lock-in. What if Atlas doesn’t perform at scale?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Good question. The Atlas platform runs the same MongoDB you’re using now, with the ability to export your data whenever you want. In terms of scale, one of our other gaming customers handled a million concurrent users during a launch with zero latency issues thanks to auto-scaling and global clusters.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: That’s… interesting. How’s security handled, especially with compliance? We have a lot of under-18 users.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Absolutely, security’s huge. Atlas is certified for SOC 2, GDPR, and other standards. We have built-in encryption—both at rest and in transit—and you get full auditing features, so you can meet your compliance requirements for minors globally.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Alright. There’s a lot to unpack. Can you send over some case studies, maybe connect me with a customer in gaming?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Absolutely—I’ll send over some gaming-specific case studies today, and I can set up a call with a customer who scaled on Atlas. Would it be okay if we scheduled a quick follow-up next week to answer any new questions?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, let’s do that. Next Thursday, same time?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Perfect, I’ll block my calendar. Thanks a lot, Zhi! I’ll send those resources over shortly.
